text: ♪ So Fly For Sci ♪

Hey. Welcome back
to "So Fly For Sci,"

where I talk to the coolest
people on Earth about science.

- Hey. What about me?
- Oh, my bad.

Also the coolest people
out of this world.

- Hey, Israel.
- Hey, Jeanette.

It's one of "So Fly For Sci's"
closest friends,

and soon to be
furthest friends.

Jeanette:
Well, not that far.

Just about 250 miles
above the Earth.

Cool flight suit.
You sure know how to "rocket."

- ( canned laughter ) 
- You see what I did?

What? This old thing?
Actually, it's super new.

But it's the standard uniform
that astronauts wear
to fly in the T-38.
We use it to talk to students,

and we also wear it
on the ISS.
The ISS? What's that?

Jeanette: ISS stands for
International Space Station.

It's what I'll live on
out in the galaxy.

Wow. Can you tell me
what your most excited about?

Well, what excites me
most is when I fly,

I'll get to see the Earth
from a new vantage point.

I'll also get
the chance to conduct
some really cool experiments,
like growing plants in space.

Wow. What did you have to do
to become an astronaut?
Well, to become an astronaut,

I had to stay in school
a really long time

to earn a PhD
in aerospace engineering.

And then I worked for ten years
as a research scientist.

Did you always want to
go into space?

Sure, I always wanted to
go into space.

However, I wasn't sure
I would get a chance.

So I focused on the things
that I could do,

like earn a PhD
in aerospace engineering.
But here I am.

Well, how different is life
going to be up there?

Like, will you be able to eat
your favorite foods in space?

We won't have things
like baked lasagna, steak,
or even a cheeseburger.

But we'll have things
that we love,

like, I like tortillas
and peanut butter
and sweet and sour pork.

Hey, I've always
wanted to ask this.

If there isn't any water
and gravity up there,

how do you do things
like cook and shower?

- Doesn't water just float?
- You are correct, Israel.
There's no gravity.
But we do have water

that we can use
for various things.

We have system called
the potable water dispenser

that we can use to rehydrate
food for drinking water,

as well as taking
sponge baths.
Whoa. How does the toilet work?

Does the water spin
to the left or to the right?

Well, in space,
the toilet doesn't spin
to the left or to the right.

And unlike camping,
we actually have three toilets

on the International
Space Station.

It's different from the one
that you would find in your home

because it works like
a vacuum cleaner.

It pulls in all the waste
so that it doesn't float away.

Wow. You learn something
new every day.

Thanks for hanging out with us
on "So Fly For Sci."

See you later.
Have fun in space.

- Bye, Israel.
- ♪ So Fly For Sci ♪
